main_definition: Baseline refers to a starting point, standard, or reference used as a basis for comparison in various contexts such as business, research, medical studies etc.

meanings_and_examples.definition: In finance and business, baseline is the initial set of data against which future changes are measured
meanings_and_examples.example: The company's financial performance last year served as a baseline for this fiscal year's projections.

meanings_and_examples.definition: In research or medical studies, baseline refers to the collection of initial data before an intervention is applied
meanings_and_examples.example: Before starting the new drug trial, scientists collected baseline data on patients' health conditions.

meanings_and_examples.definition: In sports and physical training, a baseline can refer to an athlete's performance level prior to beginning specific training or improvement strategies
meanings_and_examples.example: Before starting the strength training program, Tom established his current lifting capacity as the baseline.

meanings_and_examples.definition: In construction and engineering, a baseline can refer to an initial set of measurements used for comparison in quality control checks
meanings_and_examples.example: The building's structural integrity was assessed against the established baseline after its completion.

meanings_and_examples.definition: In communication, 'baseline' may be used colloquially to suggest a minimal or basic level of performance or expectation
meanings_and_examples.example: His work is at a baseline standard; he needs to improve it significantly for promotions.
